predictions.reference: may you grant me old age in your city

predictions.reference: and swallowed for four days

This follows the same pattern as example 512 "wnm r hrw 1" (to be eaten for one day) and example 37 "n hrww 7" (for seven days). This is a dosage instruction commonly found in Egyptian medical papyri.

The verb Dar suggests tilting or leaning, while DAt refers to a hand or the act of restraining. The imagery evokes the concept that a balance cannot be tilted when properly controlled, paralleling similar expressions in the text about justice (cf. metadata.notes: This is a common divine epithet. "nb" means "lord/master" and "AbDw" is the ancient Egyptian name for Abydos, one of the most important religious sites in ancient Egypt, particularly associated with the cult of Osiris.

predictions.reference: he said praised one

predictions.sumerian: m wDAw r tA n DAhj

predictions.reference: may he live forever

metadata.translation: may he live forever
metadata.notes: Common royal epithet/wish formula. "anx" (life/live), ".w" (subjunctive/optative marker), "Dt" (eternity/forever). Compare with example 52 "anx .w Dt pAy .n nb" (may he live forever our lord).

predictions.reference: gold horus mighty of being

metadata.notes: This is a royal titulary element. "Hr nbw" (gold horus) is one of the five royal names of Egyptian pharaohs. "sxm" means "powerful/mighty" and "xprw" means "forms/manifestations." This epithet emphasizes the divine power and transformative nature of the king.

predictions.reference: who cannot be turned away

predictions.reference: about whom a lie has been told involving a man

predictions.reference: i have overpowered mankind

predictions.reference: may he live forever

metadata.translation: king's daughter, king's sister, sovereign
metadata.notes: This is a sequence of royal titles. "sAt nsw" (king's daughter), "snt nsw" (king's sister), and "jty" (sovereign/ruler). These are common titulary elements found in Egyptian royal inscriptions, typically describing a royal woman who held multiple important positions.

predictions.reference: i fill his house
predictions.prediction: i fill his house

metadata.translation: i fill his house
metadata.notes: This phrase appears in the examples (Example 636) with the exact same translation. The structure is: mH (fill) + .j (1st person suffix "I") + pr (house) + .f (3rd person masculine suffix "his").

predictions.reference: and lebanon cedar

metadata.translation: beloved
metadata.notes: The word "mrw" is the passive participle of the verb "mri" (to love), meaning "beloved" or "loved one." It frequently appears in royal titles and epithets, such as "mrw ra" (beloved of Re) seen in Example 928.

predictions.reference: is without end
predictions.prediction: is without end

metadata.translation: is without end
metadata.notes: This phrase appears as Example 155 in the provided examples. "nn" is a negation particle meaning "there is not/without", "wn" means "to be/exist", and "pHwj.fj" refers to "its end/limit" (with the dual suffix .fj indicating the concept of "end/boundary"). The phrase is a common formulaic expression indicating eternal or limitless nature.

predictions.reference: their guidance does not stray
predictions.prediction: their guidance did not go astray

metadata.translation: their guidance did not go astray
metadata.notes: The verb nnm means "to stray" or "to go astray." The negation n at the beginning negates the action. The suffix .sn (their) attaches to sSm (guidance/leading). The construction suggests "their guidance did not wander/stray."

predictions.reference: you will be praising this after years
predictions.prediction: may you praise this every year

metadata.translation: may you praise this every year
metadata.notes: Hsy (praise) with .tn (you, plural) suffix, nn (this), m xt (after/every), rnpt (year). The construction suggests a wish or exhortation for annual commemoration or praise.

predictions.reference: the mind has stopped and cannot remember the day before

metadata.translation: hearts are forgetful of yesterday
metadata.notes: jb = heart(s); tm.w = complete/finished (here functioning as "forgetful" or "oblivious"); n sxA.n.f = of remembering; sf = yesterday. The phrase describes hearts that have ceased to remember the past.

predictions.reference: in fat of pintail duck

metadata.translation: horus who loves his place
metadata.notes: Hr (Horus) + mrHt (love/anoint) + st (place/seat). The phrase likely refers to Horus as one who loves or is devoted to his throne/place. Alternative reading could interpret mrHt as "oil/ointment" but the construction with st suggests "love" is more appropriate here as a divine epithet.

predictions.reference: the good god who seizes with his arm
predictions.prediction: the good god who seizes with his strong arm

metadata.notes: nTr nfr = "the good god" (common royal epithet); jT = "seize/take"; m = preposition "with"; xpS = "strong arm/scimitar" (symbol of royal power); .f = possessive suffix "his". This is a standard royal epithet describing the king's military prowess.

predictions.reference: she is in the house
predictions.prediction: she is in the house

metadata.translation: she is in the house
metadata.notes: Simple declarative sentence with the sentence particle jw, feminine suffix pronoun .s (she/it), preposition m (in), and pr (house). Compare with example 806: "jw sAt .j m pr" = "my daughter is in the house"

predictions.reference: a thousand of bread beer
predictions.prediction: a thousand of bread and beer

metadata.translation: a thousand of bread and beer
metadata.notes: Standard offering formula component. "t" (bread) and "Hnqt" (beer) are the two most common offerings in Egyptian funerary texts, with "1000" indicating a thousand of each - a conventional large quantity in offering lists.

predictions.reference: at the head of his entire army
predictions.prediction: at the head of his entire army

metadata.translation: at the head of his entire army
metadata.notes: m tp n = "at the head of"; mSA = "army"; .f = "his" (possessive suffix); tm = "entire/all". This is a common military phrase describing a leader commanding the full force of his troops.

predictions.reference: "hathor second month """" day 9 """""

metadata.translation: hathor second month day 9
metadata.notes: This appears to be a date notation associated with the goddess Hathor. The text contains: Hwt Hr (Hathor), Abd 2 (second month), sw 9 (day 9). The context suggests this is either a temple record or festival date related to Hathor worship.

predictions.reference: his majesty slew him
predictions.prediction: then his majesty was slaying

metadata.translation: then his majesty was slaying
metadata.notes: wn.jn is a narrative past construction ("then"), Hm.f is "his majesty" (literally "his servant/agency"), Hr + infinitive smA indicates progressive action "was slaying/killing". The .f suffix on smA refers back to the subject (his majesty).

predictions.sumerian: jsT sw wtx .w Xr HAt Hm .f r ky tA

predictions.sumerian: jxt nb jm tA mrj mj wDDt m stp sA a.w.s.

predictions.reference: i speak truthfully
predictions.prediction: i speak in truth

metadata.translation: i speak in truth
metadata.notes: The phrase follows standard Egyptian syntax: Dd (speak/say) + .j (1st person singular suffix "I") + m (preposition "in/with") + mAat (truth/justice). This is a common formulaic expression in Egyptian texts, particularly in autobiographical inscriptions where officials assert their truthfulness.

predictions.sumerian: jn jw mAat pw pA Dd
predictions.reference: is the saying true
predictions.prediction: is what is said the truth

metadata.translation: is what is said the truth
metadata.notes: This is a rhetorical question. "jn" introduces a question, "jw" is the sentence particle, "mAat" means "truth/justice", "pw" is a demonstrative pronoun "this/that", and "pA Dd" means "what is said" (the saying/the speech). The sentence questions whether what has been spoken is truthful.

predictions.reference: to whom secret matters are told
predictions.prediction: to whom secret matters are told

metadata.translation: to whom secret matters are told

predictions.reference: wenen nefer

metadata.translation: Wenennefer
metadata.notes: Wenennefer (wnn nfr) is an epithet of Osiris meaning "the one who is perpetually good/beautiful" or "he who continues to be perfect." It is composed of wnn (to be/exist/continue) + nfr (good/beautiful/perfect). This is one of the most common epithets of Osiris in Egyptian religious texts.

predictions.reference: he divided the great river along its middle
predictions.prediction: he divided the great river along its middle

metadata.translation: he divided the great river along its middle

predictions.reference: dont speak falsehood

metadata.translation: do not speak falsehood
metadata.notes: This is a negative imperative construction. "m" is the negative imperative particle meaning "do not", "Dd" means "speak/say", and "grg" means "falsehood/lie". This phrase appears in moral/wisdom literature contexts, advising against dishonesty. Compare with Example 528 "m Dd grg ntk jwsw" (do not speak falsehood for you are the balance).

predictions.reference: whom can i talk to today

The phrase "Dd .j n m mjn" literally breaks down as: Dd.j (I say/speak), n (to), m (whom/what), mjn (today). This formulaic expression appears multiple times in the examples and represents the despairing question of the protagonist.

predictions.reference: whom can i talk to today

The phrase uses the interrogative construction with Dd (to say/speak) + .j (first person suffix) + n (preposition "to") + m (interrogative "whom") + mjn (today).

metadata.notes: The phrase combines the conditional/desiderative construction "m mrr .Tn" (as you wish/desire) with "Hs Tn nTrw .Tn njwtjw" (your city gods praise you). Compare with Example 10 "Hs Tn nTrw .Tn" (as your gods praise you) and Example 530 "Xr Hswt nt nTrw .Tn njwtjw" (in the favour of your city gods). The .Tn suffix indicates second person plural possession.

predictions.prediction: he moored at dawn

metadata.translation: he moored at dawn
metadata.notes: agn = to moor/dock (a boat); .f = third person masculine singular suffix (he); m = preposition (at/in); HD = dawn/daybreak. The construction follows standard Egyptian VSO order with the verb agn followed by the pronominal suffix indicating the subject.

predictions.reference: it is that there is fright in my body
predictions.prediction: it is a terror that is in my body

metadata.translation: it is a terror that is in my body
metadata.notes: Hrt (terror/fear) + pw (demonstrative "it is") + wnn.s (it being, with .s feminine suffix referring back to Hrt) + m Xt.j (in my body, with .j first person possessive suffix). The construction "X pw wnn.s m Y" means "it is X that is in Y".

predictions.reference: who passes eternity
predictions.prediction: who traverses eternity

metadata.translation: who traverses eternity
metadata.notes: The term 'sbb' means to traverse or pass through, and 'nHH' refers to eternity or infinite time. This phrase is commonly used in Egyptian religious texts as an epithet describing divine beings or the deceased who travel through eternal time.

metadata.notes: grg = "to found/establish"; njwt = "town/city"; n = preposition "for/of"; mrytj = "the beloved one" (passive participle with definite article). The phrase likely refers to the establishment of a settlement dedicated to or for a beloved person, possibly a deity or royal figure.

predictions.reference: i didnt know whether i was dead or alive

metadata.translation: i did not know my mother during my life
metadata.notes: The sentence contains: n (negation), rx .j (I knew, with 1st person suffix), mwt .j (my mother, with 1st person suffix), r (preposition, here indicating duration/during), anx .j (my life, with 1st person suffix). The negation n with the sDm.f form indicates a past negative statement.

predictions.reference: then it is ground
predictions.prediction: then it is ground up

metadata.translation: then it is ground up
metadata.notes: This is a medical/pharmaceutical instruction. "xr .tw" is a sequential particle meaning "then" followed by passive ".tw" construction. "nD .tw .s" means "it is ground" with the feminine suffix ".s" referring to a previously mentioned substance. This type of passive construction with ".tw" is common in Egyptian medical texts describing preparation procedures.

predictions.reference: under the majesty of
predictions.prediction: now the majesty of

metadata.translation: now the majesty of
metadata.notes: The phrase "xr Hm n" combines the particle "xr" (now/then) with "Hm" (majesty) and the genitive preposition "n" (of). This is a common formulaic introduction in royal Egyptian texts, typically followed by a deity or king's name. Compare with examples like "xr m xt" (now afterwards) and "Hm n ra" (majesty of re) in the provided corpus.
